channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Shelling Raises Fears Ukraine Conflict Is Heating Up
item.description: Russian-backed separatists say they came under attack, raising fears in the West that Moscow may claim an opening for military action. Ukraine said the separatists shelled a kindergarten, wounding three people.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier on Wednesday near Katerynivka, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Ukraine Crisis Rattles Europe After 30 Years of Peace
item.description: The happy complacency of post-Cold War peace is being shattered by Russia’s threats, demands and massive military buildup around Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: German armored vehicles being deployed to Lithuania to reinforce the NATO mission there.

item.title: Canada Live Updates: Police Prepare to Clamp Down on Protesters
item.description: Ottawa’s interim police chief said officers had established a perimeter to prevent others from joining the demonstrators who have been occupying the capital for three weeks.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Police vehicles and municipal buses at a convention center near the airport in Ottawa.

item.title: As Omicron Surges, South Korea Eases Pandemic Interference
item.description: With Omicron spreading quickly, the government says it will focus on the most vulnerable, while asking others to look after themselves at home.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Waiting for coronavirus tests at a makeshift testing site in Seoul this month.

item.title: First Arabic Film by Netflix Stirs Fierce Morality Debate
item.description: Critics argued that the remake of the Italian film “Perfect Strangers” flouted moral standards by projecting Western norms out of sync with the largely religious public across much of the Arab world.
item.dc:creator: Mona El-Naggar
item.media:credit: Rudy Bou Chebel/Netflix, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Cast members of the Arabic-language version of Netflix’s “Perfect Strangers.”

item.title: African and European Leaders Meet Against Backdrop of Enduring Problems
item.description: A top-level meeting of all E.U. leaders and 40 African counterparts aims to reset the relationship as a partnership of equals. But migration and vaccine equity remain obstacles.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff

item.title: London Police Officers Charged Over Offensive WhatsApp Messages
item.description: The messages were uncovered during the investigation into Wayne Couzens, a London police officer who kidnapped, raped and murdered Sarah Everard in March 2021.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: People left tributes and messages in South London last year for Sarah Everard, who was killed by a police officer.

item.title: A Charity Led By Prince Charles Is Investigated As Prince Andrew Settles
item.description: A day after Prince Andrew settled a sexual assault lawsuit, the police announced they were investigating a charity led by Prince Charles.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II, who is celebrating seven decades on the throne this year, at Windsor Castle on Wednesday.

item.title: France Announces Troop Withdrawal From Mali After 9-Year Campaign
item.description: The pullout came after a falling out between France and Mali, in West Africa, ending a military effort that failed to drive out violent extremists.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi, Ruth Maclean and Aurelien Breeden
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: French Foreign Legion troops in northeastern Mali in 2020. Thousands of French soldiers there have been fighting an elusive enemy that is growing in reach.

item.title: What Does Russia Want in Ukraine? The Tensions Explained
item.description: Here’s a guide to the causes behind a conflict that threatens to become a major military clash, and what’s at stake for Russia, the U.S. and NATO.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier patrolling the front lines in Avdiivka, Ukraine, on Dec. 2. Tensions between Ukraine and Russia have been simmering since 2014.

item.title: Kuwait Overturns Law Used to Prosecute Trans People
item.description: The country’s constitutional court said the law, which criminalized “imitation of the opposite sex,” violated Kuwaitis’ rights to personal freedom.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Kuwait overturned a 2007 law that was used to arrest transgender people.

item.title: Afghans Find Room for Debate on Twitter Spaces
item.description: An audio live chat feature on Twitter has become a go-to place for Afghans still recovering from the collapse of the former government and seeking answers on everything from what went wrong to what comes next.
item.dc:creator: Sharif Hassan
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shopkeepers in a deserted Kabul shop, checking social media on their phones to pass the time.

item.title: On the Edge of a Polish Forest, Where Some of Putin’s Darkest Fears Lurk
item.description: A U.S. missile facility in Poland is at the heart of an issue animating the Kremlin’s calculations over whether to go to war against Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Decommissioned Soviet-era warplanes outside a U.S. base in the village of Redzikowo, Poland.

item.title: Mudslides in Brazil Kill at Least 94 People
item.description: Intense rainfall caused mudslides and flooding that destroyed part of the city of Petrópolis, in a region where a similar disaster in 2011 killed more than 900.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters digging for survivors on Wednesday in Petrópolis, Brazil. The rains that caused the mudslides were the heaviest the city had seen since 1952, officials said.

item.title: Police in Ottawa Mobilize for an ‘Imminent’ Crackdown on Protest
item.description: After weeks of truckers and others blocking border crossings and streets in the capital city, the demonstrations appeared to be nearing an end.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir, Ian Austen, Richard Pérez-Peña and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers moving protesters near Parliament Hill in Ottawa on Thursday.

item.title: United States Hopes to Deter a Russian Invasion of Ukraine
item.description: “If Russia doesn’t invade Ukraine, then we will be relieved that Russia changed course,’’ Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said at the United Nations.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: U.S. Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken addressing the United Nations Security Council on Thursday. President Biden asked him to make a speech only hours before.

item.title: Ukraine Fighting May Open Door to Russian Invasion, U.S. Warns
item.description: As shelling intensified in the east, officials warned that Moscow might use false claims of “genocide” against Russians in the region as a pretext for an attack.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A tank exercise in eastern Ukraine was cancelled on Thursday amid jitters about an impending Russian attack.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Russia May Invade in ‘Coming Days,’ U.S. Warns
item.description: Shelling in eastern Ukraine raises fears of an escalation.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers moved weapons Thursday amid the looming threat of invasion by Russia.

item.title: How a Fringe Protest in Canada Became a Very Big Deal
item.description: Even after the last trucks are gone, the demonstrations will serve as a template for how small groups can draw intense interest.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Mike Johnson in his truck outside Parliament Hill in Ottawa on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Army Troops Arrive in Poland to Reassure Allies
item.description: Nearly 5,000 soldiers from the 82nd Airborne Division are now in Poland in response to the Russian deployments on Ukraine’s borders.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: The 82nd Airborne troops, from Fort Bragg, N.C., are expected to train with Polish forces at several locations around the country.

item.title: N.Y.C. Anime Convention Was Not a Superspreader Event, C.D.C. Finds
item.description: The rate of positive results among attendees who took coronavirus tests was about the same as that of New York City at large, researchers found.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Javits, Jacob K, Convention Center (Manhattan, NY)
item.media:description: The Anime NYC convention in New York last November.

item.title: Iran Nuclear Deal Inches Toward Revival but Faces Critics in U.S.
item.description: Republicans warned that any new agreement would “likely be torn up” by the next administration.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: A satellite image of the Natanz nuclear facility in Isfahan, Iran in 2020.

item.title: Australia Authorizes Moderna’s Covid Vaccine for Children Ages 6 to 11
item.description: The country is the first to grant provisional authority for the Moderna vaccine to be used in children younger than 12.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine is already widely used in Australia in adults and adolescents. A 12-year-old boy received his first dose in Brisbane in September.

item.title: Friendly Police Response to Protests Raises Questions Among Canadians
item.description: Images on social media contrast the response to the truckers with heavy-handed action last year against Indigenous people who blocked logging.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Royal Canadian Mounted Police arresting a protester near the Fairy Creek anti-logging blockade on Vancouver Island last September.

item.title: Belarusian leader says exercises with Russia are not a sign of an imminent invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus speaking to journalists on Thursday during joint military exercises with Russia.

item.title: Rosalie Kunoth-Monks, Champion of Indigenous Peoples, Dies at 85
item.description: As a teenager, she was the star of a film about an Aboriginal girl raised by a white family. As an adult, she fought discrimination in Australia against her people.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Rosalie Kunoth-Monks, left, was an Aboriginal rights activist who was believed to have been in the first Australian movie starring an Indigenous woman. She appeared at an event in 2014 with her granddaughter Amelia.

item.title: San Francisco ousters
item.description: Why are liberal candidates losing in liberal cities?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: London Breed, San Francisco’s mayor.

item.title: Ukraine Blames Russia-Backed Separatists for Shelling in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: “We’ve said for some time that the Russians might do something like this in order to justify a military conflict,” said the U.S. defense secretary, Lloyd J. Austin III. “So we’ll be watching this very closely.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Naatlia Slesareva, 54, a school cleaner who worked in “fairy tale” for 37 years, after a shelling in Stanytsia Luhanska, on Thursday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Western allies dispute Russia’s withdrawal claims.
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian military base near the Belarus border.

item.title: Philadelphia Drops Its Vaccine Mandate for Indoor Dining
item.description: The city introduced a new system of Covid-19 response that is tied to specific pandemic metrics and could change as the situation evolves.
item.dc:creator: Ada Petriczko
item.media:description: Customers eat at the Reading Terminal Market in Philadelphia on Wednesday, Feb. 16, 2022.

item.title: Hugo Torres, Former Rebel Turned Political Prisoner, Dies at 73
item.description: Once a guerrilla commander who helped free President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua from prison, Mr. Torres was jailed last year during a political crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez and Yubelka Mendoza
item.media:description: The former Sandinista guerrilla Hugo Torres in 2017. He was jailed last year as part of a campaign waged against opposition politicians, activists and journalists in the lead-up to Nicaragua’s national elections.

item.title: Ukraine Tensions Spike as West Accuses Russia of Lying About Troop Withdrawal
item.description: As Russia stoked hopes of a diplomatic solution and claimed to be pulling back forces from the Ukrainian border, U.S. and NATO officials accused Moscow of building up troops instead.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Anton Troianovski and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: A Ukrainian military front-line position near Katerynivka.

item.title: Defiant Protesters in Canada Brace for a Clampdown
item.description: The response of law enforcement in the nation’s capital has been painfully sluggish for many residents. But police signaled they may finally be ready to move in.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Vehicles blocking a road during a protest by truck drivers over pandemic health rules and the Trudeau government, in Ottawa on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: West Doubts Russia’s Claims
item.description: Russia said troops were ordered to pull back, but threats remain, U.S. and NATO say.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: The Ukrainian Army at a front line position near Katerynivka, in Luhansk Oblast of eastern Ukraine.

item.title: U.S. and Russian warplanes flew dangerously close to each other.
item.description: Aircraft flew close in three incidents in the eastern Mediterranean, including one in which planes came within about five feet of each other.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Russian Su-35 jet fighters performing during an air show outside Moscow, in July.

item.title: U.S. Warns Americans Abroad Not to Count on a Rescue
item.description: In Ukraine and Ethiopia, Biden officials have made clear that the 2021 Kabul airlift was a “unique” operation that won’t be repeated.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The city center of Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital. U.S. officials have stressed that, in the event of a Russian invasion, America would not rescue its citizens who remain in the country.

item.title: Organizers call for the protest in Ottawa to become too large for the police to break up.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.media:description: Danny Bulford, Vincent Gircys and Eddy Stewart Cornell, protesters representing a group responsible for blockading Canada's capital city with trucks, hold a news conference in Ottawa on Wednesday.

item.title: NATO plans to shift forces to counter Moscow’s troop buildup around Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: French soldiers taking part in a drill as part of a NATO operation in Estonia this month.

item.title: Britain Will Extend Covid Vaccine Eligibility to All Children 5 to 11
item.description: Medically vulnerable children in that age group are already being vaccinated in Britain, following guidance the committee issued in December.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Preparing a dose of a Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine at a temporary vaccination center set up inside St John’s Church in London in December.

item.title: Protesters in Ottawa are on alert after the police order them to disperse.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A police officer walked between parked trucks as he distributed a notice to protesters in Ottawa on Wednesday.

item.title: Putin's Long Table Sparks Dispute Over Who Built It
item.description: The oval behemoth, where President Vladimir V. Putin has met with world leaders, has become a subject of memes and think pieces, and now of a disagreement between furniture makers.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Raphael Minder
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany on Tuesday.

item.title: In Pictures: Ukraine holds military drills.
Harpreet Chandi Breaks Barrier With Solo Trip to South Pole
item.description: Harpreet Chandi is apparently the first woman of color to complete the expedition alone. She traveled for 40 days, pulling nearly 200 pounds of gear.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.media:description: Harpreet “Preet” Chandi, a 32-year-old captain in the British Army, at the end of her Antarctic journey. For her, it was not just a test of her physical and mental resilience, but also a way to reclaim her heritage.

item.title: Shark Kills Swimmer in Rare Death Off Sydney Coast
item.description: The fatal shark bite occurred on Wednesday near Little Bay. Mayor Dylan Parker of Randwick City, Australia, said, “To lose someone to a shark attack like this is chilling.”
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Little Bay Beach, in Sydney, Australia, on Wednesday. In recent decades, Australia has recorded an average of one fatal shark bite a year.

item.title: Museum Security Guard Adds Eyes to Painting’s Faceless Figures
item.description: The guard at a museum in Russia has been suspended after he used a pen to draw on “Three Figures,” an avant-garde painting from the 1930s.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Alyssa Lukpat
item.media:credit: The Art Newspaper Russia, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A detail from “Three Figures,” by Anna Leporskaya, after a security guard penned eyes on two of the faces in the painting.

item.title: London's Troubled Metropolitan Police Service Searches for a New Leader
item.description: The change at the top comes at an awkward moment for the Metropolitan Police Service: It is investigating the government for breaking lockdown rules and faces scrutiny for its own scandals.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Cressida Dick, front left, resigned as head of the London police service last week after facing a barrage of criticism over reports of sexism and racism on the force.

item.title: Is Ukraine Cooling?
item.description: Three explanations for the latest news.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Vladimir Putin at a news conference on Tuesday.

item.title: Omicron Reveals Hong Kong's Covid Dilemma
item.description: An Omicron surge has exposed the weaknesses of a system that was once a world leader in containing the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Patients with Covid-19 symptoms at a temporary holding area outside a hospital in Hong Kong on Tuesday.

item.title: Germany Aims to Lift Most Covid Restrictions by Spring
item.description: Now that the Omicron surge appears to have peaked, officials in Germany, Austria, Switzerland and Slovakia said they too would drop all or most of their remaining restrictions in the near future.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Police officers checking vaccination certificates at a restaurant in Hannover, Germany, in November.

item.title: The Olympians Caught Up in the U.S.-China Rivalry
item.description: American athletes of Chinese descent at the Games are targets of patriotic and even nationalistic sentiment from both countries: sometimes adoring, sometimes hostile.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Eileen Gu celebrated her silver medal win for China in the freeski slopestyle competition on Tuesday.

item.title: Top European Court Rules E.U. Can Freeze Aid to Poland and Hungary
item.description: In a landmark decision, the European Court of Justice cleared the way for the bloc to cut billions in aid on the grounds that members are eroding rule-of-law checks and balances.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Monika Pronczuk and Benjamin Novak
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary speaking in Budapest this month. Losing out on E.U. money is a very touchy subject for Mr. Orban.

item.title: How Countries With No Snow Are Competing in the Winter Olympics
item.description: Several skiers representing countries with little snow are making their Olympic debut in Beijing, partly because of a diversity initiative that has generated controversy.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Zoran Marinovic for The New York Times
item.media:description: Skiers warming up before an Olympic qualifying race in Kolasin, Montenegro, in December.
